facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 14, 1955, of the Assam High Court at Gauhati in Criminal Appeal No. 54 of 1955

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 203 of 1956. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 14, 1955, of the Assam High Court at Gauhati in Criminal Appeal No,. 54 of 1955, arising out of the judgment and order dated May 23, 1955, of the Court of the Special Judge, Lower Assam Districts at Dhubri in Special Case No. 2 of 1954.

facts.text: Assam High Court judgment and order dated December 14, 1955, in Criminal Appeal No. 54 of 1955 arising out of Special Judge's judgment dated May 23, 1955 in Special Case No. 2 of 1954

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 203 of 1956. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 14, 1955, of the Assam High Court at Gauhati in Criminal Appeal No,. 54 of 1955, arising out of the judgment and order dated May 23, 1955, of the Court of the Special Judge, Lower Assam Districts at Dhubri in Special Case No. 2 of 1954.

facts.text: Appellant tried for offence under s. 165A IPC for abetting Khalilur Rahman in commission of offence under s. 161 IPC

anchor.surface_text: The appellant before us was tried for an offence under s. 165A of the Indian Penal Code for having abetted one Khalilur Rahman in the commission of an offence by the latter under s. 161, Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Both appellant and Khalilur Rahman convicted and sentenced to one year's rigorous imprisonment by Special Judge

anchor.surface_text: Both the appellant and Khalilur Rahman were convicted of the offences with which they were charged and sentenced to one. years rigorous imprisonment.

facts.text: High Court acquitted Khalilur Rahman but maintained conviction and sentence of appellant

anchor.surface_text: On appeal the High Court acquitted Khalilur Rahman but maintained the conviction and sentence of the appellant.

facts.text: On May 9, 1952, complainant Narendra Nath Brahma was taking two carts carrying 25 Mds. of paddy for sale to Billashiparabazar along the path by the side of river Gauranga

anchor.surface_text: The facts of this appeal are that on May 9, 1952, the complainant Narendra Nath Brahma was taking two carts carrying 25 Mds. of paddy for sale to Billashiparabazar along the path which runs by the side of the river Gauranga.

facts.text: Complainant stopped by paddy-checking Inspector Khalilur Rahman accompanied by appellant and three others

anchor.surface_text: When he had gone only a short distance he was stopped by the paddy-checking Inspector, Khalilur Rahman, who was accompanied by the appellant and three others.

facts.text: Khalilur Rahman demanded Rs. 200 as bribe and threatened seizure of cart and paddy, supported by appellant and three others

anchor.surface_text: Khalilur Rahman demanded Rs. 200 as bribe and threatened the complainant that unless the amount demanded was paid his cart and paddy would be seized. In this he was supported by the appellant and three others.

facts.text: Complainant agreed to pay Rs. 150, borrowed Rs. 100 from Surajmal Oswal, offered Rs. 80 to Khalilur Rahman

anchor.surface_text: The complainant expressed his inability to give that much amount but ultimately he agreed to pay Rs. 150. He borrowed Rs. 100 from one Surajmal Oswal out of which he offered Rs. 80 to Khalilur Rahman

facts.text: Khalilur Rahman asked complainant to hand Rs. 80 to appellant who counted the money and made it over to Khalilur Rahman

anchor.surface_text: who asked him to hand them over to the appellant who counted the money and made it over to Khalilur Rahman.

facts.text: Complainant forced to execute promissory note for Rs. 70 in favour of appellant

anchor.surface_text: The complainant was also forced to execute a promissory note for a sum of Rs. 70 in favour of the appellant

facts.text: On May 11, 1952, complainant approached appellant for refund of money and return of pronote, appellant promised but did not do so

anchor.surface_text: On May 11, 1952, the complainant approached the appellant for the refund of his money and the return of his pronote and although the appellant promised he did not do so.

facts.text: On May 11, 1952, complainant presented written complaint to Deputy Commissioner at meeting at Futkibari Middle English School describing payment of Rs. 80 and pronote for Rs. 70

anchor.surface_text: The same day there was a meeting at Futkibari Middle English School where the Deputy Commissioner was present. The complainant presented to him a written complaint describing how he was forced to pay Rs. 80 and made to execute a pronote for Rs. 70.

facts.text: Khalilur Rahman prosecuted under s. 161 IPC read with s. 5(2) Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947; appellant under s. 165A IPC

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon both Khalilur Rahman and the appellant were prosecuted, the former under s. 161, Indian Penal Code, read with s. 5(2) of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947 (2 of 1947) and the latter under s. 165A

facts.text: Special Judge convicted Khalilur Rahman under s. 161 IPC, acquitted under s. 5(2) PCA, convicted appellant for abetment

anchor.surface_text: The Special Judge found- I am fully convinced that a sum of Rs. 80 was realised from the complainant for forbearing from seizing of the paddy by the accused Khalilur Rahman, being helped and abetted by the accused Faguna Kanta Nath.

facts.text: High Court (Deka J) acquitted Khalilur Rahman of s. 161 IPC giving benefit of doubt as evidence not strong enough to prove payment to him

anchor.surface_text: On appeal Deka, J., held that from the complaint made by the complainant it was not clear that any payment was made to Khalilur Rahman. ... the evidence was not strong enough to prove payment to Khalilur Rahman and therefore he was prepared to give the benefit of doubt to Khalilur Rahman

facts.text: High Court held appellant guilty under s. 165A as money taken for payment to Khalilur Rahman as illegal gratification

anchor.surface_text: As to the appellant he was of the opinion that money was taken by him for payment to Khalilur Rahman as illegal gratification and whether he actually paid it to him or not the offence fell under s. 165A

facts.text: Supreme Court heard appeal on January 13, 1959, judgment by Kapur J.

anchor.surface_text: 1959. January 13. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by KAPUR, J.-

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed appeal and set aside conviction of appellant as Khalilur Rahman acquitted

anchor.surface_text: We therefore allow this appeal and set aside the order of conviction.

facts.text: Before demand, appellant and Khalilur Rahman went aside and had talks, then Khalilur demanded Rs. 200

anchor.surface_text: The evidence of the complainant was that before Rs. 200 was demanded from him, the appellant and Khalilur Rahman went aside and had some talks and coming together accused Khalilur Rahman demanded Rs. 200.

facts.text: Complainant learnt in bazar that Happaran Rai had been similarly treated but paid Rs. only

anchor.surface_text: The complainant learnt in the bazar that another person Happa- ram Rai had been similarly treated but he had only paid Rs.

facts.text: High Court finding: money remained with appellant and was not paid to Khalilur Rahman

anchor.surface_text: the finding of the High Court was that the money remained with him and was not paid to Khalilur Rahman

facts.text: Special Judge fully convinced Rs. 80 realised from complainant by Khalilur Rahman helped and abetted by appellant Faguna Kanta Nath

anchor.surface_text: I am fully convinced that a sum of Rs. 80 was realised from the complainant for forbearing from seizing of the paddy by the accused Khalilur Rahman, being helped and abetted by the accused Faguna Kanta Nath.

Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 14, 1955, of the Assam High Court at Gauhati in Criminal Appeal No,. 54 of 1955, arising out of the judgment and order dated May 23, 1955, of the Court of the Special Judge, Lower Assam Districts at Dhubri in Special Case No. 2 of 1954.

The appellant before us was tried for an offence under s. 165A of the Indian Penal Code for having abetted one Khalilur Rahman in the commission of an offence by the latter under s. 161, Indian Penal Code.

concepts.unlisted_description: Abetment of public servant taking gratification

anchor.surface_text: The appellant before us was tried for an offence under s. 165A of the Indian Penal Code for having abetted one Khalilur Rahman in the commission of an offence by the latter under s. 161, Indian Penal Code.

concepts.unlisted_description: Public servant taking gratification other than legal remuneration

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon both Khalilur Rahman and the appellant were prosecuted, the former under s. 161, Indian Penal Code, read with s. 5(2) of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947 (2 of 1947) and the latter under s. 165A

Section 165A is as follows S. 165A Whoever, abets any offence punishable under section 161 or section 165, whether or not that offence is committed in consequence of the abetment, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years or with fine or with both .

concepts.interpretation: Punishable whether or not the abetted offence under s.161 or s.165 is actually committed in consequence of the abetment

concepts.unlisted_description: Abetment of offence under section 161 or 165 IPC

anchor.surface_text: Abetment is defined in s. 107 arid a person abets the doing of a thing when  1 he instigates any person to do that thing or  2 engages with one or more other person or persons in any conspiracy for the doing of that thing or  3  intentionally aids, by any act or illegal omission the doing of that thing. Explanation  2  to s. 107 is as follows- Whoever,

concepts.interpretation: Abetment by (1) instigation, (2) conspiracy, or (3) intentional aiding by act or omission; aiding includes facilitating prior to or at time of commission

issues.text: Whether the conviction of the appellant for abetment under s. 165A of the Indian Penal Code can be sustained on the facts and circumstances of the case given that Khalilur Rahman has been acquitted of the offence under s. 161, Indian Penal Code

anchor.surface_text: The main argument raised on behalf of the appellant is that as Khalilur Rahman has been acquitted, on the facts and circumstances of this case the conviction of the appellant for abetment cannot be sustained.

issues.text: Whether in these circumstances the offence of abetment can be held to have been made out

anchor.surface_text: the money re- mained with him and was number paid to Khalilur Rahman the question is whether in these circumstances the offence of abetment can be held to have been made out.

anchor.surface_text: But it was contended on behalf of the respondent that the acquittal of Khalilur Rahman was wrong and this Court should hold that a wrong acquittal does number prevent the conviction of the appellant for the offence of abetment.

arguments.claim: The circumstances proved against the appellant did not bring the case under the second part of s. 107 because it is not alleged that there was any conspiracy and a charge of conspiracy must necessarily fail if the other alleged conspirator is acquitted.

arguments.claim: A person abets by aiding when by the commission of an act he intends to facilitate and does facilitate the commission thereof. By the acquittal of Khalilur Rahman the High Court must be deemed to have held that there was no offence under s. 161.

anchor.surface_text: There then remains the third part of s. 107 that is abetment by aid. A person abets by aiding when by the commission of an act he intends to facilitate and does facilitate the commission thereof By the acquittal of Khalilur Rahman the High Court must be deemed to have held that there was no offence under s. 161.

arguments.claim: The decision in Dalip Singh v. State of Punjab must be circumscribed to the peculiar circumstances of that case.

holdings.text: We are of the opinion that on the facts found and circumstances established in this case and as Khalilur Rahman has been acquitted the appellants conviction cannot be upheld.

anchor.surface_text: We are of the opinion that on the facts found and circumstances established in this case and as Khalilur Rahman has been acquitted the appellants conviction cannot be upheld.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No abetment proved under any limb of s.107 IPC (instigation, conspiracy, or aiding) given principal's acquittal and factual findings that money remained with appellant.

holdings.text: Under the Indian law for an offence of abetment it is not necessary that the offence should have been committed. A man may be guilty as an abettor whether the offence is committed or not.

anchor.surface_text: Under the Indian law for an offence of abetment it is not necessary that the offence should have been committed. A man may be guilty as an abettor whether the offence is committed or not.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of s.165A IPC which explicitly punishes abetment regardless of whether the principal offence under s.161 is committed.

holdings.text: It is not suggested that there was any instigation by the appellant for the commission of the offence.

anchor.surface_text: It is not suggested that there was any instigation by the appellant for the commission of the offence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Absence of evidence or allegation of instigation under first limb of s.107 IPC.

holdings.text: the circumstances proved against the appellant did not bring the case under the second part of s. 107 because it is not alleged that there was any conspiracy and a charge of conspiracy must necessarily fail if the other alleged conspirator is acquitted

anchor.surface_text: Further the circumstances proved against the appellant did not bring the case under the second part of s. 107 because it is not alleged that there was any conspiracy and a charge of conspiracy must necessarily fail-if the other alleged conspirator is acquitted

holdings.reasoning_summary: No allegation of conspiracy; precedent holds conspiracy charge fails upon acquittal of co-conspirator (citing The King v. Plummer and Topandas v. State of Bombay).

holdings.text: A person abets by aiding when by the commission of an act he intends to facilitate and does facilitate the commission thereof. By the acquittal of Khalilur Rahman the High Court must be deemed to have held that there was no offence under s. 161.

anchor.surface_text: There then remains the third part of s. 107 that is abetment by aid. A person abets by aiding when by the commission of an act he intends to facilitate and does facilitate the commission thereof By the acquittal of Khalilur Rahman the High Court must be deemed to have held that there was no offence under s. 161.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Acquittal of principal implies no s.161 offence occurred, so no facilitation or aiding of an offence possible under third limb of s.107 IPC.

holdings.text: The decision in that case must be circumscribed to the peculiar circumstances of that case.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Dalip Singh v. State of Punjab (s.302 r/w s.149) limited to its facts involving unlawful assembly liability, unlike individual abetment here.

holdings.text: We therefore allow this appeal and set aside the order of conviction.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore allow this appeal and set aside the order of conviction.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Consequent upon holdings that no abetment offence proved.

We therefore allow this appeal and set aside the order of companyviction.
